header.title: SORCERY/WITCHCRAFT COURSE of POWER: Lesson Two - Basic Witchcraft/Sorcery
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Practical Magic, Herbalism

central_thesis: Herbs, oils, and incenses are presented as the fundamental keystones of this course in sorcery and witchcraft, each possessing specific magical attributions for purposes such as love, power, protection, luck, and success. The text provides practical, results-oriented instructions for their preparation and application in various magical rituals, while also issuing strong warnings regarding potential dangers and the ethical implications of certain practices.

structure_content.summary: This section establishes herbs, oils, and incenses as central to the course, organizing them by magical use. It emphasizes the importance of botanical names for accurate identification, provides instructions for proper storage to maintain potency, and issues crucial warnings about the poisonous nature of some herbs and the importance of safety, especially regarding children and pets.

This chapter introduces the concept of love magic, noting the planet Venus as its ruler and suggesting that love rituals are generally performed during Venus's planetary hours. It highlights that the provided herbs are selected for their effectiveness in love spells across various traditions.

A detailed catalog of specific herbs used for love attraction, compelling, and resolving relationship issues. Each entry includes the herb's common and botanical names, its magical properties, and practical applications in rituals, such as anointing roots, carrying in charm bags, burning as incense, or adding to food and baths. Key herbs like Adam and Eve Root, Ambergris, Apple Blossoms, Basil, Bittersweet, Black Cohosh, Black Snakeroot, Cardamom, Chrysanthemum, Civet, Cloves, Coriander, Cumin, Daisy, Damiana, Devil's Bit, Dill, Dragon's Blood Reed, Elecampane, Eryngo, Fig, Gentian, Ginseng, Grains of Paradise, Hazel Leaves, Honeysuckle, Jasmine, Laurel, Lavender, Lemon, Licorice, Lignum Aloes, Lilac, Lily of the Valley, Lime, Lovage, Maidenhair, Marigold, Marjoram, Mint, Mistletoe, Musk, Myrtle, Orange Blossoms, Orris, Pansy, Passion Flowers, Patchouli, Pennyroyal, Periwinkle, Quassia, Rosebuds, Rosemary, Rue, Sage, Sarsaparilla, Skullcap, Senna, Snakeroot, Southernwood, Spikenard, Vervain, and Yerba Mate are covered.

This section provides a recipe for a 'Sure-Fire aphrodisiac formula' from the New Orleans tradition, involving eggs and lemon juice. It also mentions Damiana and Ginseng as effective aphrodisiacs, describing their preparation as teas or brandy infusions.

This note reiterates that love herbs fall into categories of attraction or problem-solving, and offers several specific recipes for love incenses and oils: 'Lovers' Incense' (Musk, Civet, Ambergris, Patchouli), 'He's Mine' (Orange Blossoms, Jasmine, Musk), and 'Goddess of Love' (Rose, Mint, Musk). It also includes 'Follow Me Boy' (Vanilla, Rose, Jasmine, Coral, Gold Glitter) as a love and legal aid potion, emphasizing Musk's commanding power.

structure_content.chapter_title: HERBS ASSOCIATED WITH POWER, COMMANDING, COMPELLING, AND PROTECTION
structure_content.summary: This extensive section details herbs primarily used for protective, commanding, and compelling magic. It covers botanical names, specific magical effects, and practical applications in charm bags, incenses, baths, floorwashes, and doll magic. It also identifies 'TWISTER' herbs that can have dual, often opposing, effects. Herbs like African Ginger, Agrimony, Agueweed/Bonset, Althea, Angelica, Asafetida, Balm of Gilead, Bay Leaves, Benzoin, Betony, Bilberry, Bindweed, Bladderwrack, Bloodroot, Borage, Brimstone, Broom Tops, Buttercup, Calamus, Caraway Seeds, Carnation, Cascara Sagrada, Cinquefoil, Clove, Comfrey Root, Curry Powder, Devil's Bit, Dogbane, Dragon's Blood Reed, Elder, Elm Bark, Eucalyptus, Fennel Seed, Foxglove, Galangal (Low John), Garlic, Hawthorn, Hazel, Holy Herb (Yerba Sante), Holy Thistle, Horehound, Jalap (High John), Marjoram, Masterwort, Mimosa Pine, Mistletoe, Motherwort, Mullein, Oak Leaves, Palma Christi Bean, Pine Needles, Quince Seed, Rowan, St. John's Wort, Slippery Elm, Sloe Berries, Snapdragon, Storax/Styrax, Tobacco, Thyme, Tormentil, and Violets are described, along with recipes for 'STOP HEX' and 'DRAGON'S BLOOD CRYSTAL BATH', and 'FIERY WALL OF PROTECTION OIL/INCENSE'.

This chapter focuses on herbs designed to attract luck and success, often with an emphasis on money drawing, gambling, or removing blockages. It discusses the role of 'catalyst' herbs like Allspice and Cinnamon. Herbs covered include Acorn, Alfalfa, Allspice, Bergamot, Bistort, Buckeye, Camomile, Cherry Blossoms, Clover, Frankincense, Gum Mastic, Heal-All, Irish Moss, Job's Tears, Juniper Berries, Lemon Verbena, Lucky Hand, Mojo Wish Beans, Nutmeg, Peony, Potato, Queen of the Meadow, Sacred Bark, Sandalwood, Sea Lettuce, Seven Barks, Smartweed, Solomon's Seal, Spearmint, Squill Root, Star Anise, Tonka Beans, Vanilla, and Yellow Dock, along with recipes for 'MONEY DRAWING POWDER', 'LUCKY LODESTONE INCENSE/OIL', 'CROWN OF SUCCESS', 'DOUBLE FAST LUCK', and 'GOOD LUCK MYSTIC'.

This section provides overarching advice, noting the overlapping categories and varied meanings of herbs across traditions. It encourages practitioners to experiment to find what works best for them and explains how the intention or accompanying ritual elements (like candle colors or other 'power herbs') can alter an herb's effects.

A series of practical questions designed to test the reader's comprehension and ability to apply the learned principles of herbal magic to various hypothetical scenarios involving love, protection, and luck, and the identification of specific herb properties and ritual components.

key_concepts.definition: Herbs, oils, and incenses are considered the fundamental building blocks and most important elements of the magical practices taught in this course.
The scientific name for an herb, provided to ensure precise identification and avoid confusion arising from common names that vary regionally.
Specific times of day or night associated with particular planets (e.g., Venus for love), considered optimal for performing rituals related to that planet's influence.
The act of applying oils to magical tools like roots or candles to charge them with specific intentions or energies, acting as a 'filter or lens to project your desires accurately'.
A small bag, often colored to match its magical purpose (e.g., red for love, green for money), used to carry herbs, roots, or other items charged with a specific magical intent.
The magical act of using herbs or fragrances to 'force or compel sexual interaction', often associated with powerful, non-selective substances like Ambergris, Civet, and Musk.

An herb capable of producing 'TWO TOTALLY OPPOSITE THINGS' or effects, such as both inflicting and reversing hexes, or creating/removing deception. Examples include Marigold, Bilberry, Bindweed, Fennel Seed, and Myrrh.
An herb, typically fiery in nature (e.g., Cinnamon, Allspice, Capsicum), that is added to mixtures to 'set other herbs in motion' and activate or increase their overall power and effectiveness.
A magical practice or ritual (and associated herbs) aimed at removing negative conditions, hexes, bad luck, or blockages that are adversely affecting a person's life.
A magical practice (and associated herbs/oils) used to influence or exert control over another person's thoughts, feelings, or actions, especially in matters of love, loyalty, or behavior.
Magical practices strictly intended for benevolent purposes or 'good', often associated with protection, healing, and positive attraction, and contrasted with Black Magick.
Magical practices explicitly warned against, particularly influencing married or committed relationships, as it is considered 'purely Black Magick' leading to negative consequences.
Herbs that affect the mind, thoughts, or intuition of individuals, often used to bring prophetic dreams, hunches, or insights for success or understanding.
Natural magnets used in luck and money drawing rituals, whose 'magnetic action forms an 'ATTRACTION' energy' to bring desires to the practitioner.
A ritual practice where iron filings are offered to a lodestone daily on an altar, while visualizing the desired outcome (e.g., money), to continuously charge and activate its attractive power.

practical_system.description: The system presented is a practical, herb-based magic system rooted in folk traditions, designed for tangible results in areas such as love, protection, and success. It operates on the principle that herbs, oils, and incenses are 'keystones' that, when properly chosen, prepared, and applied in rituals, generate specific energies or 'vibrations' to manifest desires. The system emphasizes precision through botanical names, proper storage, and careful selection based on a herb's primary and secondary magical attributions (e.g., commanding, compelling, uncrossing, aphrodisiac, protective, luck-inducing). Rituals often involve anointing items, creating charm bags, burning incenses, preparing magical baths or floorwashes, and utilizing 'catalyst' or 'twister' herbs. A strong ethical component is present, with strict warnings against 'Black Magick' applications, especially in love. The concept of 'psychic herbs' affecting the mind and intuition also features prominently.
tools: Herbs (roots, leaves, flowers, seeds, barks, resins) chosen for specific magical properties.
Occult oils (e.g., love oil, power oil, unfaithful oil, commanding oil, 'Bend Over Oil', 'Peace Oil'), often with a Grape Seed oil base.
Incenses (various herbal and resinous mixtures, sometimes with magnetic sand or gold glitter).
Powders (herbal blends, 'Stay At Home Powder', 'Unfaithful Powder', 'Confusion Powder', 'Inflammatory Confusion', 'True Love Powder').
Candles (red for love, green for money/luck, pink for innocence/love, purple for commanding/justice, blue/yellow for domestic unrest, black for hexing/banishing).
Charm bags (red for love/protection, green for money/luck).
Altar (as a central workspace for rituals).
Parchment or brown paper (for writing names or wishes).
Dove's Blood ink (for writing names in specific rituals).
Plastic boxes or containers (for herb storage in a refrigerator).
Whiskey (as a base for certain infusions or offerings).
Lemon juice and eggs (for aphrodisiac preparation).
Rock salt (for protective baths and banishing).
Shredded dollar bills (to empower money drawing oils/incenses).
Dolls (made from specific fabric colors like brown, white, or pink, with purple thread for commanding/justice).
rituals: Anointing roots or candles with specific occult oils to charge them for a desired task.
Carrying herbs in colored charm bags (e.g., red for love, green for money) for ongoing magical influence.
Burning incenses composed of various herbs and resins for attraction, compelling, protection, or banishing.

Preparing herbal teas for internal consumption (aphrodisiacs), use in bath water (for aura charging, attraction, or uncrossing), or as floorwashes (for blessing homes, attracting good times, or removing negative energies).
Placing powdered herbs or dried leaves in a target person's shoes, pockets, or around their home for influence or protection.
Using dolls (stuffed with specific herbs and made from particular fabrics/threads) for commanding individuals, stopping slander, or promoting reconciliation.
Performing love rituals during the planetary hours of Venus for optimal effectiveness.
Executing a 'Psychic Divorce' ritual by burning a former lover's hair/personal item with Snakeroot to banish them.
Ritualistically 'feeding' a lodestone (natural magnet) with iron filings on an altar while visualizing desired outcomes (e.g., money attraction) over several days.
Carving a loved one's name onto a Ginseng root, anointing it with love oil, and carrying it in a red bag.
Using specific herb mixtures (e.g., 'True Love Powder', 'Stay At Home Powder', 'Unfaithful Powder') for complex relationship issues.
Employing red candles carved with a lover's name, surrounded by herbs, and burned down completely to charge the herbs for a love charm bag.

relevant_quotes.text: WARNING: If YOU HAVE CHILDREN OR PETS, MAKE SURE THAT THEY DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO YOUR RITUAL ITEMS. NOT ONLY WILL THIS HURT YOUR RITUALS BUT, MANY HERBS ETC., ARE POISONOUS AND IF TAKEN INTERNALLY CAN CAUSE DEATH!!!

The realm of love is ruled by the planet Venus, although not all of the herbs we will discuss come under her direct power. However, when working with this kind of love ritual is it generally done during the planetary hours of Venus.

Roots are more powerful than herbs or flowers and they are viewed as being similar to candles in that they generate a kind of raw energy which is focused to a specific task through the anointment process.

One area you MUST NEVER TOUCH is, love involving a married or committed person. While it is very hard to know if a person is really committed, you should STAY AWAY FROM INFLUENCING THESE TYPES OF RELATIONSHIPS. This is purely Black Magick. If you do cause problems in this type of relationship, I hope you get every misery you deserve!
Most people are terribly Spiritually sick. To take in their energies will GREATLY HARM YOUR MAGICK.

The bottom line is what works. You need to try all the different combinations we give you to see which one works better for you. Many practitioners find one to work better for them than another as it is different for each person.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to practitioners of practical folk magic, particularly those interested in Hoodoo, New Orleans Voodoo, or similar traditions that heavily utilize herbalism. It offers a structured and direct approach to spellcraft for tangible outcomes, contrasting with more esoteric or symbolic magical systems. Its emphasis on specific recipes and detailed instructions makes it a useful operative manual.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of aspiring or novice practitioners of witchcraft and sorcery, seeking practical, results-oriented magical techniques using readily available (or Society-supplied) herbs, oils, and incenses. It is also suitable for those with an interest in the folk magic traditions of the American South and Caribbean, and individuals seeking guidance on specific life problems (love, protection, luck) through magical intervention. The warnings suggest a concern for responsible practice among new initiates.
